newsitem.title: USA: Salomon earnings slip, shares slump.
newsitem.headline: Salomon earnings slip, shares slump.

text.p: The string of strong third quarter earnings from Wall Street's brokerage firms snapped on Tuesday with a surprisingly weak report from Salomon Inc.
Until Salomon's report, brokers had generally performed as expected, falling short of the record incomes generated in the second quarter but bettering by far efforts of a year ago.

Salomon, however, failed to match even its 1995 performance, posting net income of $112 million or $0.85 per fully diluted share, down from $263 million or $2.10 per share a year ago. Analysts had expected Salomon to earn $1.19 per share, according to First Call's consensus estimate.

Shares in Salomon received a drubbing after the report, falling 3-1/4 to 45-3/8 on the day, but Wall Street analysts said a recent run-up in the shares ahead of today's report likely accounted for the sharpness of the sell-off.
Analysts were reluctant to draw too many conclusions from the quarter, because Salomon's earnings are largely linked to its trading activities for its own account, and therefore extremely volatile.

However, one aspect of the quarter did raise eyebrows: a weak showing at the firm's Phibro unit, which comprises Salomon's commodities trading and refinery operations. The unit posted a $7 million profit in the third quarter, down from $68 million a year ago.

"I'm never shocked when Salomon shows either a sharp increase or decline," said Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette analyst Joan Solotar. "But one surprise was that refining margins were up worldwide and profits at Phibro were down."
During a conference call with analysts, Salomon declined to spell out the reasons for the profit decline, but the firm did announce its exit from coal, coke and fertilizer trading.

On a bottom-line basis, Salomon's negative net revenues in equity sales and trading of $26 million had an even larger impact than the Phibro results. In the 1995 quarter, the firm's revenues there amounted to $196 million.

Analysts said most of the decline was attributable to a "mark-to-market" loss in the firm's proprietary equity arbitrage portfolio, an item that is all but impossible to forecast and not indicative of any underlying business trend.
The good news for Salomon was that underlying businesses such as investment banking showed improvement.

"(Salomon's) long-term arbitrage portfolio and Phibro's trading results will continue to report widely varying results from quarter to quarter," Brown Brothers analyst Raphael Soifer said in a research note, "but the firm's underlying performance continues to improve."
Salomon's third quarter investment banking revenues rose to $187 million in the quarter from $128 million last year.
